entry.title: Keeping the Artsakh identity alive through collective resettlement

media:group.media:title: Keeping the Artsakh identity alive through collective resettlement
media:group.media:description:
Antranig Kasbarian, Trustee and Development Director of the Tufenkian Foundation, discusses the organizationâ€™s efforts to support displaced people from Artsakh in the aftermath of the 2023 ethnic cleansing of the region. He outlines Tufenkianâ€™s new plan to resettle 20 families from Artsakh in the village of Svarants in Armeniaâ€™s Syunik province, focusing on sustainable housing and economic development. Kasbarian explains why collective resettlement is critical for preserving the regionâ€™s identity and why Syunik now plays a vital role in Armeniaâ€™s national future.
0:00- Tufenkian's prior initiatives in Artsakh 2:39- Why collectively resettle Artsakhis in Armenia? 4:30- Why Syunik for resettlement? 7:09- Phase I of resettling in Svarants village 8:43- What type of Artsakhis are being sought for this resettlement? 9:30- International NGO & Armenian government support for the project 11:00- Challenges faced 14:42- How to support the project

entry.title: Can a treaty with Azerbaijan protect Armenia?

media:group.media:title: Can a treaty with Azerbaijan protect Armenia?
media:group.media:description:
Hrair Balian, former director of the Carter Centerâ€™s Conflict Resolution Program, analyzes Armeniaâ€™s critical juncture as it pursues normalization with Azerbaijan and Turkey. Drawing on decades of experience and his forthcoming book on the failure of the Nagorno-Karabakh peace talks, Balian offers a sober look at the potential of a normalization treaty with Azerbaijan. He addresses public skepticism and fears of renewed aggression, and emphasizes that there can be no peace treaty without the release of the Armenian prisoners held in Baku.

entry.title: Thomas de Waal: â€œThe Geo-History of Russian-Turkish Rivalry on the Black Seaâ€

media:group.media:title: Thomas de Waal: â€œThe Geo-History of Russian-Turkish Rivalry on the Black Seaâ€
media:group.media:description:
Thomas de Waal, British journalist, author, and Senior Fellow at Carnegie Europe, delivered a lecture titled â€œThe Straits: The Geo-History of Russian-Turkish Rivalry on the Black Seaâ€ on June 25 in Batumi. The event was part of a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey.
The 2025 Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Batumi, Yerevan, and Tbilisi from June 25 to July 13.
